sentences.sentence: By Mark Penninga and John SikkemaThe Liberal government tabled legislation on Monday to broaden Canada's laws restricting "medical assistance in dying" (MAID) because a Quebec judge ruled last September that "assisted dying" should be available to those who are not dying, but may have many years to live.

Before rushing to satisfy the demands for more open access to MAID, Parliament should pause and consider what trajectory we are on and whether there is a better way to respond to the increasingly common requests for state-sponsored suicide.Our nation has three options.
First, respond to requests for medically assisted suicide as we would to all others who want to end their own life: offering support, care, and suicide prevention.
Second, allow MAID in very limited situations, such as when people are suffering and near death.

Third, show total deference for human autonomy by allowing MAID for anyone who wants to end their life.Before the Supreme Court of Canada's 2015 Carter decision allowing assisted suicide, Parliament overwhelmingly defeated more than a dozen bills that would have legalized the practice, maintaining that life is sacred and the right to life can't be extinguished, even if someone doesn't think their own life is worth living.

Although Parliament passed Bill C-14 in response to the Carter decision, thinking it could follow option two, the fact that Parliament is already broadening MAID proves that it is quickly sliding to option three.Our Liberal government accepted the Quebec judge's decision that we should allow doctors to kill people who are not dying.

The Ministry of Justice explained that the government "will expand eligibility for MAID beyond people who are nearing the end of life, and could possibly also result in other changes once the review is complete.
"Parliament had good reason to include the "reasonably foreseeable natural death" restriction, and the previous Liberal government itself championed its passage.
So it is striking that the government did not defend Parliament's law by appealing the Quebec judge's ruling.

Instead, this Liberal government jumped at the opportunity to change the law to reflect that ruling.If it really is an unconstitutional restraint on autonomy to limit MAID to those who are nearing their natural death, the dominos will continue to fall.
How can we justify not extending assisted suicide to those whose suffering is psychological, or to teens or children, or to someone whose only reason for MAID is that they are tired of living?
Many MAID proponents don't hide the fact that their goal is unrestricted access to any Canadian who wants assisted suicide.

As the Quebec ruling shows, all they have to do is find one sympathetic judge somewhere in the country to keep extending the "right to assisted death" to more and more people.Many MAID proponents don't hide the fact that their goal is unrestricted access to any Canadian who wants assisted suicide, write Mark Penninga and John Sikkema.The track we are going down doesn't merely lead to a future where a wide variety of people will be killed by "medical professionals" with taxpayer funding and government approval.

Rather, it will mean the erosion of our moral and legal fabric founded on respect for human life as intrinsically dignified, worthy, and inviolable - which is the foundation for human rights.As the Universal Declaration of Human Rights recognizes, human beings, simply because they are human, possess a basic dignity which is the "foundation of justice and peace in the world" and the basis of human rights.
Paramount among these is the right to life.
Every human being deserves equal protection by the law regardless of their health, abilities, or feelings of self-worth.

Legally condoning the elective forfeiture of one's own right to life (as in the case of assisted suicide) or the judgment of doctors or society that some people's lives are no longer worth living subverts basic human dignity and the moral foundation for human rights.
It is Parliament's duty to think beyond the heart-wrenching stories that illicit widespread public sympathy and make decisions that uphold the social fabric as a whole.Dr.

Leo Alexander, an investigator for the Nuremberg Trials and contributor to the Nuremberg Code wrote the following in the New England Journal of Medicine in 1949: "whatever proportions these crimes finally assumed, it became evident to all who investigated them that they started from small beginnings....
It started with the acceptance of the attitude, basic to the euthanasia movement, that there is such a thing as a life not worthy to be lived.
"Parliament can still prohibit assisted suicide and consensual homicide completely, as it always had until 2016.

The Supreme Court of Canada's Carter decision does not prevent it from doing so.Although it takes courage, it isn't too late to recognize that a mistake has been made and that our nation should be doing everything it can to provide palliative care and suicide prevention rather than state-sanctioned killing.Mark Penninga is the Executive Director of ARPA Canada, a Christian non-profit advocacy group that intervened in the Carter Supreme Court case (2015), the BC Supreme Court Lamb case (2019) and presented before the Parliamentary committee that examined C-14.John Sikkema is a constitutional lawyer with ARPA Canada.K.
